This is a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13626 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13192 but I can't mark it such currently. This nut has a FreeCAD source file which allows for parametric configuration of number of holes, hole spacing, nut width, etc. It is part of the MendelMax redesign, and the latest official version will live at https://github.com/maxbots/MendelMax/blob/master/partsrc/TSlotNut.py
After printing, insert a low profile (thin) M5 nut into the bottom and slide the assembly into your t-slot extrusion.

I was getting some warping on the larger parts when printing in ABS so I added some print bed anchors. Worked perfect for me so I thought I would share the files in case anyone else needs them.
I also remixed the handle to be one piece, a little longer, and a bit beefier.
And I added shoulders to the studs on the base which helps make the assembly more rigid.

Get the hardware and other parts from the original design by andrewSORG (under "remixed from" on the right).

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a customizable filament spool hub. It will allow for some error margin in the roll hole size. It's designed to work with or without a bearing. You can customize the filament hole size, bearing diameters and more. Try it in the customizer, edit the .SCAD file, or use the provided STL, which is a version that fits a eSUN 1kg spool (52mm diameter hole) with a standard skate (608) bearing.

Please share your makes :)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

i3 Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Notes:

Be careful when removing it from the build platform, if you grab it and bend the legs that are pointing up, there's a chance that the layers will split. I've made angled edges so it will be easier to pry it off.

I find that it prints best with PLA, I've also done a few in PETG which works, but it's slightly less firm. I imagine it will work fine with ABS too.

This is a snap-in pipe clip that fits in the center slot of 1.5" 8020. Like my other 8020 snacks, this one hold the 8020 tight and won't slide without a LOT of force. A piece of 1" PVC pipe snaps right in and is held firmly in place.
I use it in my printer to hold two filament feed reels. There is another piece of pipe a little further forward that keeps the filament away from the Z-axis drive belt and provides almost perfect vertical feed to the extruder.
I printed using 0.2mm layer thickness with 25% fill, and neither raft nor brim.  I printed with support material, so a little clean up was necessary after removing from the print bed.

author: ALUCINE

description.text:
I saw the awesome video of Nicolas Vuignier
(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aqncOP7OzMg)
I wanted to try it, i don't have an iphone so i adjusted it in sketchup

I downloaded the original file from here http://www.centriphone.me/

If you are going to print this, note that I am not a professional designer so don't blame me if your phone flies away. The measurements are quit tight so you will need to sand the inside a bit. If you have print it, show me!
(sorry for the bad english i don't speak english)

This is a model christmas tree printable on the makerbot with a slot to insert a coin battery and an LED to illuminate the piece from inside! Merry Christmas and Happy Printing!  
Update: corrected a bug in the model that made it print without the base!  
Also, this updated version is smaller then the previous one avoiding some problems while printing the top
Just print the tree, insert the coin battery between the LED legs as in a throwie ( http://www.instructables.com/id/LED-Throwies/ ) and insert the group in the slot on the bottom of the Thing

comments.text: Sweet lil thing!  I always knew it was exactly what I was going to print first when I got my printer.  Oddly, I always thought it was totally hollow, illuminated simply by covering a light underneath.  What a pleasant surprise when I printed it tonight and noticed that you actually built in space for a battery and led!!  Our minds are somehow going in the same direction because I've been just recently making some little lights with led housings over at shapeways.  It's really cool to see how yourhousing  is different, more simple, and yet effective.

title: OpenSCAD Build of Allted's MPCNC IE V4

description.text:
OpenSCAD rebuid of Allted's Mostly_Printed_CNC International Edition V4.0

The original is at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790533

Some updates and minor modifications by jpmendes and others.

LICENSE: Creative commons non commercial

This is a work in progress.

TODO: Make it more parameterizable
Put animation to work.

Note: The prefix "IE" stands for International Edition, designed for 25mm diameter pipes assembly.

Do not contact me or Allted, the original author, about issues related with this project.

If you are interested in parts or kits Allted sells them at: http://www.vicious1.com/
but have in mind that not all the parts, namely the corner locks, presented here are originals.

My corner locks have additional holes to insert screws for wood or plastic do better distribute pressure and relief the stress of the captive nuts boxes of the corner locks. Holes have to be drilled carefully on the original corner blocks.

Screw threads are not represented because representation of a thread is very processor power demanding.
Some modules are pre-rendered, so you have to wait until rendering completes.

For the belts representation you should have access to list-comprehension-demos and scad-utils libraries, I think both are available with the standard OpenSCAD installation.

This ships with no guarantees at all.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

description.text:
This is a bracket I designed to use for motor focusing with my telescope. It fits the Skywatcher Startravel 102 focuser and holds a Nema 17 PG25 stepper motor. Possibly fits other telescope focusers but there was no working bracket model for my specific scope.

The design includes adjustable length for a perfect fit and slits for using straps to fasten the stepper motor and connector.

Works wonders - it's rock solid and doesn't flex when focusing. Do check out the MyAscomFocuser project if you want to build something like this yourself!

Print it using supports for holes and slits. I used 50% infill just to be sure it won't flex when focusing.

50%

Notes:
  • Choose a higher infill percentage than the default 20% to eliminate flexing.
  • Use supports for the holes and strap slits.
  • Rotate it so the fully flat side is down.

Hi all 3D printer fanatics out there!

I have a problem I can't figure out whats wrong. Maybe some one out there have a clue what the issue can be!

I have drawn a detail in 123D design. Exported it as sal with the settings "fine". Imported in Simplify3D and tried to print it out. After approx. 7 mm of printing hight there seems to be a week layer and i can't figure out why. I tried to print a similar detail 2 weeks ago and that part shows exactly the same symptom. I have a Vertex 8402 3D printer and run this project with black ABS with a temperature about 230 degrees at a speed of 2400 mm/min.

Take a look att the images and see if you have a clue. i'm most grateful to anyone how can bring some light into my darkness.

Vertex 8402

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1 mm

40%

Black ABS from Vellerman.

comments.text: Hi everyone!
comments.author: Lommen

comments.text: Remember this one trick in Simplify 3D and it will prevent a lot of failed prints. Ctrl+L then click the surface you want touching the bed. Never trust just dropping the model to the bed.
comments.author: Lommen

comments.text: You should NOT run the cooling fan with ABS. Use it only with PLA.  As you have discovered ABS is very sensitive to the slightest breeze, so running a fan will warp your print. I only print with ABS and found out the hard way a while back. Set your S3D to have fan speed 0 at layer 1 so the fan won't turn on. I have that set in all my configuration profiles for ABS.
comments.author: Lommen

comments.text:
Might be a division error due to a layer height not fitting to your z lead screw.
You could try to calculate the optimal layer height with the prusa calculater, and adjust your settings accordingly.
http://prusaprinters.org/calculator/#optimallayer

comments.author: Zulan

comments.text: I would try slicing it again and running  it through the free version of netfab (unless you have the paid version). I've had that problem before and it was fixed by re-slicing.  You could also double check some of your settings in simplify3d (there's so many that it's easy to goof one up on accident). As a side note, I don't think there's anything wrong with using a fan on ABS (depending on the situation and the settings). I've noticed an increase in print quality when done right.

comments.author: Centus

comments.text: I see nothing wrong with the file itself, but there are a few settings I would play with. Assuming that you are printing in ABS, My settings are a lot different. I usually run ABS at about 248c with a bed temp of 108c. This would be a drastic change for you and filament brand plays a large part in what is right as well as ambient temp, so I would try bumping the temp up in 5 degree increments. Also try bumping up your extrusion multiplier. I think you are reducing the amount of plastic extruded by too much. Between too little plastic, weak layer adhesion, cooling, and the natural stress of trying to curve while being held down to the bed splitting can occur and often does around the same place.
comments.author: MagicEngineer

The room temperature is 19,7 degrees and I'm using a heated bed at 90 degrees. I printing another part right now and this part is printed to 62% now, approx 12 mm but is not showing this problem. The first part printed 2 weeks ago was the first roll of ABS. I have just change to a new one, not because of this problem. I have printed a lot of parts so I emptied the previous roll.

title: Rubber Band Guns (TOY) - Romulus and Remus

description.text:
PLEASE NOTE: THESE ARE DESIGNED AS TOYS AND/OR COLLECTIBLE ITEMS AND ARE NOT MEANT IN ANY WAY AS WEAPONS AND ARE MERELY FOR FUN AND PLAY. I have no intention of them ever being anything more than a harmless toy and I believe that they stay within the community guidelines, if not please let me know and I'll take the files down, I don't mean to cause offence or uproar.

A pair of rubber band guns to be made from plywood (4mm) in layers.
The central slide that allows the trigger mechanism to work is sprung in an alive at the top. It also connects to an external slider on either side that can be pulled for slam firing.
The rubber bands are loaded onto the rotary "hammer", which is pulled backwards and latches with the slide and trigger. There is also a fang shaped rubber band holder/magazine built into the front of the gun. Theoretically by opening the magazine by sliding the latch then pulling the gap between the "fangs" across the top of the gun's twin you can reload it.

Named after the twins of Roman legend, Romulus and Remus are similarly painted black except the highlighting of one is red and the other is gold.

The STLs should help, I've included some images showing the assembly and the pdf provides templates for gluing and cutting directly from plywood.

title: Quick release plate for Manfrotto 484rc2 ball head

description.text:
This is a replacement quick release plate which fits a Manfrotto 484rc2 ball head. The design in openscad can be parametrized to change the holes.  
As is, it features two holes for mounting Allied/Prosilica cameras (GC-650 for example). One such cameras is shown in the gallery.  
I hope this plate can be usefull to attach non standard cameras or other things. Just modify the openscad model file.

You can just print the manfrotto484rc2-plate.stl file, but this features holes for a prosilica cameras.  
Instead, you can load the model in openscad and generate a more "generic" model, or one with your favorite hole configuration. See the comments in the scad file.  Also, the model can be adjusted easily in the scad file.  
Note that a text logo has been added to the model (just to see if it could be made...). To remove this, set use_logo to false in the scad file. This also explains the v3d-blender.stl file, which provides the logo.

title: Lens Cap for Canon SX230HS Camera

description.text: This cap protects the camera's fragile lens cover leaves and keeps pocket fuzz out of the lens elements inside the turret.

I carry a Canon SX230HS camera in my pocket so I have a good camera with me at all times. Unfortunately, the front cover of the lens turret consists of the thinnest possible aluminum, so pressing the camera's front side against anything bends the cover against the leaves and jams them closed. This lens cap solves that problem with a sheet-metal plate that bears against the non-moving turret rim. The plastic ring spaces the plate away from the cover by two thread thicknesses, allowing the plate to absorb all the pressure without touching the lens turret. The plate recess uses a built-in support ring that you remove by twisting each small tab with a needle-nose pliers. A dab of acrylic adhesive holds the plate in place. The bright yellow filament is sufficiently hideous that I probably won't leave the cover behind. Conversely, should I turn the camera on with the cover in place, the camera shuts itself off with a lens error; this doesn't seem to do any harm. The OpenSCAD code has enough parameters that you should be able to adapt it to any camera. Even if you have a Canon SX230HS, you should regenerate the STL file to match your printer's thread dimensions to ensure a snug fit. More details on my blog:
http://softsolder.com/2011/11/12/canon-sx230hs-lens-cap/

comments.text: Can't you just print over that hole instead of requiring a plate of sheet-metal?
comments.author: polymaker

comments.text: It's a two-way tradeoff: the cap must be both thin and stiff. A millimeter-thick plastic sheet would be quite bendy across that 44 mm opening, but the metal disk doesn't flex at all.
comments.author: polymaker

comments.text: Seen as you have spent some time on this.. do you think this lens cap (http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/125286-REG/Kaiser_206953_53mm_Push_On_Lens_Cap.html)http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/... will fit ok on my SX220? Is 53mm to small? :)
comments.author: ednisley

comments.text: The SX230HS turret has a 53 mm OD and the first comment for that cap says it fits fine on a 230. It should also fit on the 220, as well, because the only difference is not having the GPS bump on the top.

remixed_from.title: Customizable Lens Clip for Note4VR / OpenDive headsets

title: Customizable Lens Clip for VR Visors (Single- or Dual- Lens)

description.text:
This is an evolution of my old Lens Clip: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:634507
It can generate the same things as that one, but also has DUAL LENS SUPPORT!

I haven't yet come to any conclusions about whether more lenses means better quality, but this provides an avenue to play with that idea.

You'll want all of your lenses to be roughly the same diameter, but you can tweak each diameter individually.

The Math

Basically, treat two lenses' focal lengths like two resistors in series. So two 100mm lenses together will make ~50mm focal length.

But the distance d between the lenses makes a difference. So really:

Fab = (Fa * Fb) / (Fa + Fb - d)

The Distance D of the front focal plane from the nearer lens:

D = Fab * (Fb - d) / Fb

So, with two 100mm focal-length 40mm lenses spaced 11mm apart, my true focal length Fab would be 52.9mm. The distance D to the nearer lens would be 47.1mm.

Why buy a birthday card when you can make one? Design based on my original foldable cube and rectangular prism designs which use a single thin layer as a hinge. Check out http://designmaketeach.com/2013/07/26/foldable-rectangular-prism-visual-tinkercad-tutorial/ for design tips on this construction method. I personalized the card design with an inside inscription. The age of the recipient was positioned so that it could be seen through the heart shaped cutout when the card is folded closed. Tie the card shut with a ribbon or design an 'envelope' to hold the card.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2IogSsJWbWc

Text was colored with Sharpie but I could have paused printer and swapped filament mid-print for a two-toned card. Yes, the recipient thought it was awesome.

Find me on Twitter or Instagram @DesignMakeTeach

description.text:
My Printer was having some oozing issues, and I needed to test my retraction settings. I read a great and simple article on the subject (https://www.matterhackers.com/articles/retraction-just-say-no-to-oozing) but was unable to download the STL. So I created one quickly in TInkerCad. It is just 4 10mm Cubes that are spaced 10mm/20mm/40mm apart.

This is a great way to test and start to hone in the appropriate retraction, ooze control, and other settings. Let me know if this helps you out.

Keep on printing!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Frank the Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Use your default.

Infill:

10%

Notes:

You can use this with your "Standard" printing settings. I did mine at .2mm layers to start, and also then at .1 and .3mm layers.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online, I made it in about 2 minutes
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dzb7DVnatnh

comments.text: This worked great for me. Just for reference - I'm printing Wood-PLA on an Anet A8. The prints come out pretty decent w/ the Cura Anet A8 Golden Ratio Speed/Quality settings, except there is alot of oozing / stringing with Wood-PLA, not so bad with regular PLA.

remixed_from.title: MPCNC - Original corner block with limit switches Remix for US & IE Version

title: MPCNC - Top Plate for Tall Corners with Mech Limit Switch Mounts for US & IE Version

description.text:
Rev8 Update
I changed the wire covers a little & made a zip tie connection on the side for the limit swtich wires to route easier.

This plate adds a way to put mechanical limit switches on top of the corners. The Y-Limit switch was too far above plate to hit the roller, so I remixed the roller lock to add a surface for the switch to hit. The plate is the same for both US & IE versions & I made a roller lock part for both versions.

This works with: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1401177 & probably also the totem mpcnc corner design. I made 2 versions of the clamps. One uses the teeth of the belt to match teeth cut into the plastic & the other uses a double up to a single width for the belt to clamp it. I am leaning towards the double up design, since it is easier to insert the belt & also.

After installing all the test parts together, I may change the way the belt tensioner works. It seems like the belt is too far away from the corner block.

author: GeoDave

description.text:
This is a box I designed for carrying my protoboard to the university labs safety.
The size of the protoboard is 11cm x 16,5cm and it fits tight, so be careful with tolerances.

A friend of mine lost his battery clip on his Ducati 748. And because he changed his battery to another model (MotoBatt) the original wouldn't have fitted anymore anyway.
I added the text "748" with avrgeeks OpenSCAD League Gothic Font Module thingiverse.com/thing:6820.
The motorcycle dxf I got from mydxf.blogspot.com

For another battery or motorcycle the dimension can be modified in the OpenSCAD file.
Print and mount.

Tailor's chalk sharpener. Keeps the edges of the chalk narrow (90°) for narrow marks on the cloth. Just grate away the the thick edges of the chalk.

[Update 2016.05.17] Added a version with a steeper angle (45°) for longer sharpness durabilty

Notes:

Important: Keep print orientation as given. In such a way the fins of the grater will be sharp (layer height) and not round (extrusion width).

Here is a design of an extruder mount for the Kossel Mini. It features a pushfit for 4mm OD 2mm ID PFA Tubing with a M5 threaded mount. Uses the Planetary Geared Box Stepper and the 8mm Shaft filament drive gear. All of these components can be found at www.makercoast.com

Print Settings Infill : 95%
Layer Height : .2mm
Parameters: 2 You need:
-- 4x M3x8 ( 2 for motor and 2 to mount to extrusion )
-- 1x M3x25 ( for idler )
-- 2x M3x30 ( for Motor )
-- 2x M3 nut ( for idler )
-- 4x M3 washer ( for Springs )
-- 2 x M3x45 ( for idler )
-- 2x spring or piece of rubber diesel pipe (see Airtripper's original)
-- M5 pneumatic push-fit adapter ( Mcmaster PN : 5225K503 )
-- 1 x 608 bearing for idler
-- 1 x M8 X 16 for idler bearing (you can substitute with a smooth rod 16mm length)
-- 8mm Shaft Drive Gear : http://makercoast.com/product/hobbed-drive-gear
-- 2ft PFA Tubing : http://makercoast.com/product/pfa-tube
-- Planetary Gear Stepper : http://makercoast.com/product/geared-stepper-motor

title: Big Emergency / Panic Button for MySensors / pimatic

description.text:
Emergency Button

This is some big Emergency Button. I use it with my HouseAutomation to control things and stuff.

As button itself i use a black Cherry MX switch that i had laying around. Works nice :)

When it was printed i thought a lower height would be great, so i added a 15mm/piece version. The version in the video is 30mm/piece.

What you need to do it like me:

  • all three printed parts
  • Cherry MX switch of your choice (i got mine from Conrad Germany
  • Arduino
  • NRF24L01+ Radio
  • some cables
  • some M3 Screws (M3x30+ should do fine)

You can read more about that stuff here:

  • Software i use pimatic.org
  • Hardware i use mysensors.org

Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jMr5voq1hkA

I stole the idea for fixing the knob to the switch from ohagel. Thanks buddy, mine creation did not work as expected ;)

Update v2

I changed the plate thickness of the top part from 1mm to 1.5mm, that should make the Cherry Switch fit much better.

Update v3

I think using one cherry switch is great. But using 4 cherry switches is even four times greater. So i added a top and a knob that can handle 4 cherry switches. I made one, and it feels very good. Sadly yellow is empty, so mine is gray.

Update v4

Added CAD files. Please be nice, i am not that good at it.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,15mm & 0,25mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed on my Ultimaker2 and sliced with Simplify3D.
Print "Knopf" with support, but remove possible support on the part that slides on the cherry switch.

Mine version is printed pretty fast and not best quality, since it should be a prototyp. But works, so who cares ¯\(ツ)/¯

Push the big red knob onto the Cherry switch. Maybe you need some sharp knive and remove the "elefant foot". It should fit tight.

Cable it up like a mess, isulate the electronics stuff and throw inside the button. Then close and screw together.

author: GIWillys

print_settings.Notes:: I tried really hard to not use support material as extensively but I failed. Take your time removing the support and it should come out pretty nice.

description.text:
This remix is somewhat different. I have a smaller 3D printer that has an extruder that uses the bearing holder as the spring. It also has no accessibility because the filament path is very close to the hobbed gear. I still don't like the direct drive extruders because it seems they stall at the slightest "oops" and you have to clean the filament drive teeth anytime it happens.

This extruder uses the Accessible Wade's Extruder and kind of removes the accessible by moving the filament path as close to the drive as possible. I also use a 12mm filament drive gear. I do add two springs to add just a small amount of tension to improve grip.

Note: I have installed this extruder and it works great so far. With 1.75mm filament, there is little place for the filament to bend and get stuck.

Printer:

Home built

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I tried really hard to not use support material as extensively but I failed. Take your time removing the support and it should come out pretty nice.

BOM

3- 608 Bearings
2- .5" x .25" C-510 spring
2- 1-5/8" 6-32 bolt
1- 1/4" 6-32 bolt
4- 6-32 nuts
2- 6-32 flat washer
1- 5/16" x 2.5" bolt
1- 5/16" nut
2- 1/4" washer (These still fit over 5/16" bolts)
1- 5/16" all-thread cut to 3/4"
1- extruder gear with 5/16" or 8mm i.d.

Assembly

After spending too much time cleaning support material, start by assembling the driven gear set.

Take the 5/16" nut and drill and tap it for 6-32. This makes a great lock nut. Use the 1/4" 6-32 bolt as the set screw.

Push the 5/16" bolt through the driven gear. Place one washer on the bolt then a bearing and then the extruder gear. Insert this into the extruder body. Place a bearing on the bolt then a washer then the nut. Do not tighten the nut too tight, remember it is only plastic. Tighten the set screw to hold the nut in position.

Line up the extruder gear with the filament guide. I found that if you insert a piece of filament through the extruder, it will help hold the extruder gear in place. Tighten the set screw on the extruder gear.

For a test, spin the assembly. I had to mill out the extruder gear because all I had was 5mm i.d. version. This made my set screw too tall. If your set screw is too tall, you will have to drill an indention into the bolt. Do the best you can. When I drilled the bolt, I was a little off. If you notice in the picture, there are two paper washers to move the bolt assembly left by .040".

Cut the all thread to length. I used a dremel cutoff tool to make a slot in the top. This really helps for assembly and removal. Insert the last bearing into the tensioner and insert the all thread as the shaft. I like the all thread because the threads help keep it in place.

Place the long 6-32 bolts and springs as shown. There should not be much tension on the springs because the bearing already has a preloaded tension on the extruder gear. The springs are there to help maintain a constant tension. Tighten until the spring just contact the plastic.

Install the stepper motor, drive gear and J-Head hotend as you would for any extruder.

title: Universal Laser Attachment for 3D Printers Stand Alone System ARDUINO CODE Updated 8/28/2013

description.text:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_ah5ApzHw8Q&feature=youtu.be
-STAND ALONE LASER ATTACHMENT SYSTEM FOR REPRAP STYLE 3D PRINTERS- CAUTION- LASERS ARE DANGEROUS AND WILL BLIND/BURN ANYONE IN VISUAL RANGE IF YOU DO NOT TAKE PROPER PRECAUTIONS OUTLINE IN INDUSTRY STANDARDS. GOOGLE THEM BECAUSE I AM NOT AN EXPERT ON THEM. -BY USING THIS SYSTEM, CODE, IDEA, HARDWARE, SOFTWARE OR ANYTHING RELATED YOU, AND ONLY YOU ARE TAKING FULL RESPONSABILITY FOR THE SAFTY OF ANY PERSONS/PROPERTY THAT MAY BE AFFECTED BY ITS USE/MISUSE. I JAMES SESLER AM NOT LIABLE FOR DAMAGES OF ANY TYPE. I AM RELEASING THIS AS IDEA AND CODE AS OPEN SOURCE WITH THE HOPES IT WILL BE USEFULL TO THE COMMUNITY BUT ALSO WITH NO PROMISE THAT IT WILL BE USEFULL TO ANYONE. -switch a laser driver circuit on and off. NOW with SAFETY toggle OR DOOR switch AND LIGHT 8/26/2013- James Sesler August 23 2013 ADDED SAFETY SWITCH AND VISUAL ON AUGUST 26 2013
1) This sketch reads the voltage from a small DC motor or other source
on Analog Pin "0". 2) If the voltage is higher than the set voltage it triggers digital pin 9 to go high. 3) That HIGH 5v signal triggers a switch "MOSFET" transistor to allow power to flow to a laser driver circuit, relay, motor, or other load. 4) The dc motor it to be attached to the extruder's stepper motor shaft on a RepRap style 3D Printer so when the stepper is turning that laser will be active and when the stepper stops turning the laser will shut off. This allows a person to use their 3D printer as a laser cutter/engraver without firmware or hardware modification. Simply remove the filament from your extruder, turn down the heat and clip on the laser diode. ----------------->To create the tool paths follow this example of cutting a square:<-------------- a) Creat a 3d model of a square that is the same height as a single layer you would 3d print at, usually .3mm b) Make the wall thickness the same as your printers extruder nozzle so your slicing program only generates one pass. c) Turn down the x,y,z travel speed so it moves very slow BUT turn UP the extruder speed so when it turns the DC motor this sketch will be able to detect a sufficent voltage. This sketch should help with creating the model correctly to get the slicer to generate the code correctly -->\ \<-- Nozzle diameter Usually .35mm - .4mm
\ \

Instructions on how to make the system are in the arduino Code. If you have any questions let me know. This is a work in progress. I have successfully make it work on a bread board but I have not fully implemented it because of a lack of time. I still need a lense to focus the Laser. The included .stl files are pretty universal and should work with most extruder motors and work with whatever small DC Motor you have.

title: Socket Retainer Kit / Socket Rail Organizer

description.text: In an effort to teach myself how to model (slightly) more complex, and interlocking shapes in SketchUp; as well as being disgusted with how expensive these stupid things can cost I decided to "make" my own. This set includes dongles which should fit 1/4", 3/8" and 1/2" drive sockets; labled 25, 375 and 50 respectiely. I must point out however that my 3D Printer is on back-order so they are COMPLETELY untested however I think I did the math right and gave proper clearances. The STL's load fine in both Cura 13.06.4 and Repetier 0.90c; as well as a "virtual" print in Repetier runs fine. Cura reports a cost of ~1USD per rail assuming a cost of ~30USD/kg of ABS @ 75% Fill, the dongles being ~0.15 to 0.21USD depending on which size at the same fill. The rails have little nibs on each end stopping the "dongles" from sliding off once you squeeze them on; and the dongles themselves have nibs which should keep your sockets reasonably secured. The rails measure 180mm; which should fit on a 150mm (6") print bed if you rotate it 45 degrees. Also listed is a "one sided" rail, with nibs on one end only so you can glue or ABS fuse two rails together. If anyone actually prints these off; please post a comment and picture of how it turned out; I'd really like to hammer out any kinks before my printer actually arrives :-D

title: The 100th Upload - Tantalus Cup
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Thingiverse tells me this is my 100th design.

Nope.

More like the 126th.

But to celebrate the home page of BathRobotics now saying "100 DESIGNS" I thought I'd do a pre-tested Print of a Trophy. Not just any trophy though. If You fill this cup with water, it will completely empty itself.

I've designed in a self supporting pathway for the water from the centre of the cup to just below the brim and then down again to the base. Once the water reaches the top of the channel it forms a syphon and empties the cup.

NEW VERSION IS V3 - COMPLETE WITH "BLANK" AS PER REQUEST

This one works ("GOOD"), The smaller one (also included) didn't do too well, but that might be my printer. I've just re-demo'd it and the Syphon had water still in it, so kicked off as soon as water went in.

Give a Shake before using a 2nd time.

So, 100, in Bath (Aqua Sulis) I might be a Roman Centurion!

(Except I'm from Liverpool originally)...

100 Design uploads, that's dizzy heights right there. With Schrohr, Zheng3, AdaFruit, WilliamAAdams, Mark Durbin, Tony Buser, and Greg Zumwalt, all of whom have managed at least 100 uploads too.

IN TIME FOR GOOD FRIDAY
-This makes a brilliant Egg Cup for large eggs, Chocolate Eggs, Easter Eggs, or scale it for Hens Eggs - just don't drop it.

Respect peeps,

EUR ING Andy Southern
aka
Bath Robotics.

title: Cable Guide for EM Fantasy / CTC / Flashforge / Rep X2

description.text:
Hello guys, I have been fiddling around with a complete cable chain remix that was easy enough to print and looked decent.

I recommend printing the parts in ABS or PETG as PLA is a bit too brittle and you may find links breaks in areas where connection is made. I have the tinkercad link for some of these also (my modified ones) if someone wishes to make adjustments, the links themselves will click together fine and also come apart with a sharp knife to separate the links carefully at their connector mid sections.

I recommend printing the chain link sections with a 7 brim at 200microns, the box connector bit will need internal supports obviously.

For printing the main cable/tube collar system you may find it difficult to keep from lifting off the platform as its large, so try a DOUBLE layer brim of 7-12 and be sure you nozzle is up pretty close platform.

  • For the remaining parts please refer to Coberdas source (rings and tube screws).

Note: You may notice the cable link on each end is angled, this is intentional to compensate for slack that occurs due to weight of the whole thing, honestly this whole chain took me WAY to long to modify and get right, I went through several iterations before falling on this one!

comments.text: Looks nice!
comments.author: coberdas

comments.text: Would just like to mention that the models in areas look a little dodgy but they print out all fine so I didn't really bother doing any excessive cleanup. If you print at 50 or 100 microns MAYBE you will see some imperfections but printing at that resolution would be pretty silly :)

description.text:
Phone holder for the iPhone 6 and 6s that slides into the cd slot on a car stereo (Mini in my case). It holds the phone with no case very securely, could be scaled up to fit a case. I've include the stl and sketchup files.

Total width is 100mm to print on an M3D or similar printer. I used Black PLA.

I did have an issue with the wedge curling at the ends, but this turned out to be a neutral to positive thing as it ensures a solid hold in the CD slot. There is a notch on the bottom to fit the big lightning adapter.

In black it is barely noticeable in the car, of course it does block the knobs and buttons somewhat in a 2011 mini.
